9FC61B4EE9094ADB97A462461E8549F9.description:
Reflection acknowledges
the impact of actions on both the
group and individual contributions,
noting the reasons for such actions,
assumptions made, and whether or
not such actions and assumptions
hindered or helped the achievement
of the group’s and individuals’ tasks.

99360DD46D0A4DBAA2804EBCB203D8AB.description:
Reflecting on experiences
of collaborative effort.

63361EFBFE794E588D829EFF47960AE6.description:
Learning requires practice
through an iterative process of
thinking/rethinking, vision/revision,
and writing/rewriting

B27C3944D4EF451CA3BAAD7D240EF5DB.description:
Reflection is an ongoing
and recursive process in inquiry, often
leading to changes in understanding.
Strategies for reflection may include
journal writing, self-questioning,
drawing, exploration of space, and/or
guided contemplation.

DD243F4FA1B54DEE98FA31D01555638E.description:
Reflecting on and revising
their own writing, thinking, and
creative processes.

16B6CD9B7A3D4487B18A299BC614D12D.description:
Reflection increases
learning, self-awareness, and
personal growth through
identification and evaluation of
personal conclusions and their
implications.

3A2669CD170045EF9892A4822698A569.description:
Effective teams consider
the use of online collaborative tools.

C497AB7D105E47A799F8ED7EDF4CA1CB.description:
Teams function at their best
when they practice effective
interpersonal communication,
consensus building, conflict
resolution, and negotiation.

B8C381C3D3844259A3C4DF5DBFC78F72.description:
Teams function at their best
when they understand the diversity
of their social–cultural perspectives,
talents, and skills.

F242BEBFCAAF462CAEF62AA534013134.description:
Teams are built around
tasks. Low-risk teambuilding activities
and simulations enhance a team’s
performance.

364001731B2A4F6DBC753E706344CA2D.description:
Fostering constructive
team climate, resolving conflicts,
and facilitating the contributions
of all team members to address
complex, open-ended problems.

F629F16F511B46FBAAC89E49C6F4DEDD.description:
Knowing and communicating
one’s strengths and challenges to a
group allows one’s contributions to be
more effective.

F2F92BF488854E968D8F677AF8EDC148.description:
Providing individual
contributions to overall
collaborative effort to accomplish
a task or goal.

EEAAB4AFF9264CD89760F890F705FC71.description:
Teams are most
effective when they draw on the
diverse perspectives, skills, and
backgrounds of team members
to address complex, open-ended
problems.

9B57670C2FB242C28BEF12325885B665.description:
Speakers vary elements
of delivery (e.g., volume, tempo,
movement, eye contact, vocal variety,
energy) to emphasize information,
convey tone, and engage their audience.

5EE2E8E6BF2F4862A33275222BBB1086.description:
Engaging an audience by
employing effective techniques of
delivery or performance.

37FB2DBCDF2F4335A529D16718B7B48D.description:
Arguments can be adapted by
strategically selecting and emphasizing
information considering audience,
situation, medium, and purpose.

58BE5B6115E3466DBC25657DB3B99D3B.description:
Adapting an argument for
context, purpose, and/or audience.

1A3C413C35FF4793878C9764205B3126.description:
Effective communication
requires choosing appropriate media
(e.g., essay, poster, oral presentation,
documentary, research report/thesis)
according to context, purpose, and
audience.

15FE9C43AA994621A82331C0D4EDA193.description:
Data and other information
can be presented graphically (e.g.,
infographics, graphs, tables, models)
to aid audience understanding and
interpretation.

B1A9A4681A0E4BC7A7E7D0CAA3AEBF43.description:
Effective organizational and
design elements (e.g., headings, layout,
illustrations, pull quotes, captions,
lists) may aid in audience engagement
and understanding by calling attention
to important information and/or
creating emotional responses in the
audience. Ineffective use or overuse
of these elements disrupts audience
engagement and understanding.

32140473B3AD49F496E3E7C48EB2695E.description:
Communicating
information through appropriate
media using effective techniques
of design.

0284E6EC814C440A9551216E6E4BC1F8.description:
Spelling and grammar
errors detract from credibility.

6603DD7CE84643B79CF1571468A74E0D.description:
Precision in word choice
reduces confusion, wordiness, and
redundancy.

43A8E448FAA14791AA65F0F7302B2105.description:
Effective sentences create
variety, emphasis, and interest
through structure, agreement of
elements, placement of modifiers,
and consistency of tense.

98CCAEC2E1384E5D83F3D30D3B858C4A.description:
A writer expresses tone
or attitude about a topic through
word choice, sentence structure, and
imagery.

0D3DD8B27ADB4E8098B81137C498EE08.description:
Adhering to established
conventions of grammar, usage,
style, and mechanics.

4363A94D92C64DD3B307CBDB02E7491B.description:
Coherence is achieved
when the elements and ideas in an
argument flow logically and smoothly.
Transitions are used to move the
audience from one element or idea to
another by illustrating the relationship
between the elements or ideas.

6E9E8B733F31485EBB5E932CFDFC806A.description:
An argument may include
the following elements: Introduction: engages the audience by providing background and/or context; Thesis: conveys the main idea of an argument; Reasons, evidence, and commentary: provide support for the argument; Counterargument, concession, refutation, and rebuttal: acknowledge and/or respond to opposing arguments; Conclusion: synthesizes reasoning, considers possible implications for the future, and ties back to the introduction; Bibliography: identifies works cited.

4444099874164597A785CB6CA3504431.description:
Planning, producing, and
presenting a cohesive argument,
considering audience, context, and
purpose.

469BC196E25E4952A414531B70EFE2BE.description:
How a perspective or
argument is presented affects how
people interpret or react to it. The
same perspective or argument
may be developed and presented
differently depending on audience,
purpose, and context.

511A096EE3A94D7198FF0EA507DB448D.description:
When making choices and proposing solutions,
the advantages and disadvantages of
the options and alternatives should
be weighed against the goal within its
context.

5816839DB3764FE18C0431399F69A4CA.description:
Offering resolutions,
conclusions, and/or solutions
based on evidence considering
limitations and implications.

BC5AE4938A654EB6AD5187E1D3392E9D.description:
Arguments, choices,
and solutions present intended
and unintended opportunities, and
consequences.

678E79AD16FE45EF9F245E2AE8DA9673.description:
Innovative solutions and
arguments identify and challenge
assumptions, acknowledge the
importance of content, imagine and
explore alternatives, and engage in
reflective skepticism.

B732A310DF0741D39D5892E0018913AE.description:
Extending an idea,
question, process, or product
to innovate or create new
understandings.

8B0F98403A0140549F5F6E57E30F65FC.description:
Forming one’s own
perspective and reaching new
understandings involve innovative
thinking and synthesis of existing
knowledge with personally
generated evidence.

2906DD9F676B4AE2833F7E00C067F022.description:
Academic disciplines use
specific style guides for citing and
attributing sources (e.g., APA, MLA,
Chicago, AMA).

0D81614C7BEF475886233DA203F85E67.description:
Quoted and paraphrased
material must be properly attributed,
credited, and cited following a style
manual. Quoting is using the exact
words of others; paraphrasing is
restating an idea in one’s own words.

E40D569306764BD1B2399445F99EAA78.description:
Source material should be
introduced, integrated, or embedded
into the text of an argument.

61408369968A4D2D803D5A8545341111.description:
Plagiarism is a serious
offense that occurs when a person
presents another’s ideas or words as
his or her own. Plagiarism may be
avoided by acknowledging sources
thoroughly and accurately

A5E05C8C201D486F9F2AD52C23B443A5.description:
Accurate and ethical
attribution enhances one’s credibility.

D0B0C867F2534BBB812F4E9596A0DD53.description:
Attributing knowledge
and ideas accurately and ethically,
using an appropriate citation style.

9D9FBF155A23418891E2213B4BF67729.description:
Responsible participation
in the scholarly community
requires acknowledging and
respecting the prior findings and
contributions of others.

543C94064AAD4A459105787A7FC47D5F.description:
Commentary connects the
chosen evidence to the claim through
interpretation or inference, identifying
patterns, describing trends, and/or
explaining relationships (e.g.,
comparative, causal, correlational).

8D6992EE1DAA43E98324021F8DE3C39D.description:
Providing insightful and
cogent commentary that links
evidence with claims.

073757E168A243268060A2E09DDDAB0E.description:
The evidence selected and
attributed contributes to establishing
the credibility of one’s own argument.

A21F90A1D891431C8A8D1802E66B62F0.description:
Evidence is strategically
chosen based on context, purpose,
and audience. Evidence may be used
to align an argument with authority;
to define a concept, illustrate a
process, or clarify a statement; to set
a mood; to provide an example; to
amplify or qualify a point.

2334DA4A2BD349B2BA9A7D6D0F279220.description:
Evidence is used to
support the claims and reasoning of
an argument. Compelling evidence
is sufficient, accurate, relevant,
current, and credible to support the
conclusion.

28D7414D494843D6B636C1F5E4574010.description:
Evidence can be collected
from print and non-print sources
(e.g., libraries, museums, archives),
experts, or data gathered in the field
(e.g., interviews, questionnaires,
observations).

429F2D6FDC06422CB2071EDB10E25285.description:
Interpreting, using, and
synthesizing qualitative and/or
quantitative data/information from
various perspectives and sources
(e.g., primary, secondary, print,
non-print) to develop and support
an argument.

9E63D1B683ED4CC79770677FD748DBA7.description:
Scholars responsibly and
purposefully engage with the
evidence to develop a compelling
argument or aesthetic rationale.

8BF6CB7D37B247198115F75307B50167.description:
The same argument may be
organized, arranged, or supported in
multiple ways depending on audience
and context.

239062E02D7245138AC9951455F262A2.description:
Claims and supporting
evidence are arranged (e.g., spatially,
chronologically, order of importance)
to convey reasoning and relationship
(e.g., comparative, causal,
correlational).

A4CBC894D2194425896EA110B2F2A2A4.description:
A line of reasoning is
organized based on the argument’s
purpose (e.g., to show causality, to
evaluate, to define, to propose a
solution).

1692EB11250D4543B7FDC60B3D94B44D.description:
The logic and reasoning of
an argument may be deductive (claim
followed by evidence) or inductive
(evidence leads to a conclusion).

6A3E645EEA3B462982156D3ED8B485B8.description:
The line of reasoning is
a clear, logical path leading the
audience through the reasons to a
conclusion.

2F4F289E311C41CF87B4CD36E8160F66.description:
Effective arguments
acknowledge other arguments
and/or respond to them with
counterarguments (e.g., concession,
refutation, rebuttal).

B83C47CDF5E4415994E0A4382E64FB4F.description:
Qualifiers place limits
on how far a claim may be carried.
Effective arguments acknowledge
these limits, increasing credibility
by reducing overgeneralization or
oversimplification.

DB49A27705D342D1AF59F85A1DB2DC0D.description:
Effective arguments are
supported and unified by carefully
chosen and connected claims,
reasons, and evidence.

2822FA5C18754B3693ECCCF5BDAA88E3.description:
Effective arguments use
reason and evidence to convey a
perspective, point of view, or some
version of the truth that is stated or
implied in the thesis and/or conclusion.

69D60FE8C7764CD398EDFDDFEAFC5769.description:
Formulating a wellreasoned argument, taking the
complexities of the problem or
issue into consideration.

2A32007D83C74A60B523F25C9A2EC7FF.description:
Scholarly works convey
perspectives and demonstrate
effective lines of reasoning
that have been selected for the
intended audience, purpose, and
situation.

38B5A30EAB694D369ED1AA2D60C7B9BF.description:
When evaluating multiple
perspectives or arguments,
consideration must be given to
how one’s own personal biases and
assumptions can influence one’s
judgment.

12EF493CF0BC409496598FBE24C98AF5.description:
Critical thinkers are aware
that some arguments may appeal
to emotions, core values, personal
biases and assumptions, and logic.

37A48D42400B4143B9AABD71E3F286D6.description:
Evaluating objections,
implications, and limitations of
alternate, opposing, or competing
perspectives or arguments.

8DCE2EF4F6D040AD8EB4D9DC62CF3D32.description:
Not all arguments are
equal; some arguments are
more credible/valid than others.
Through evaluating others’
arguments, one’s own arguments
can be situated within a larger
conversation.

60EDBD2D195048AE8ECB8E14D0400361.description:
Perspectives are not always
oppositional; they may be concurring,
complementary, or competing.

B80DDEEE0832405DBFB843FC90572C6A.description:
An individual’s perspective
is influenced by his or her background
(e.g., experiences, culture, education),
assumptions, and worldview, as well
as by external sources.

3EF04C576BFF4EFAA2F56B3DBC6DA553.description:
Identifying, comparing,
and interpreting multiple
perspectives on or arguments
about an issue.

DEF7F4730CBA432A877FF84E7BC05C61.description:
Different perspectives
often lead to competing and
alternative arguments. The
complexity of an issue emerges
when people bring these differing,
multiple perspectives to the
conversation.

88245A82F56B4E53B8C2B876621B968A.description:
Arguments are significant and
have real-world impact because they
can influence behavior (e.g., call one to
action, suggest logical next steps).

75480A980F4947299E7A5652BA4F50FB.description:
Evaluating potential
resolutions, conclusions, or
solutions to problems or issues
raised by an argument.

B224DB1FBFDE42858A163529AC342234.description:
The implications and
consequences of arguments may be
intended or unintended.

A9FF0E9189304299BF1CD745222B267A.description:
Connecting an argument
to broader issues by examining the
implications of the author’s claim.

0A58714D79794FFCA40D3FE06DA16A89.description:
An argument is valid when
there is logical alignment between
the line of reasoning and the
conclusion.

056DD97DF4944BA0BF41191A6E5E2192.description:
Evaluating the validity of
an argument.

92BDC1FE7AA54261B86800E08AB4C116.description:
Credibility is compromised
when authors fail to acknowledge
and/or consider the limitations of
their conclusions, opposing views or
perspectives, and/or their own biases.

337FB2265BB34E01AC8D5AEB44A00619.description:
Evidence may be used to
identify and explain relationships
(comparative, causal, or correlational)
and/or patterns and trends.

6E57FE7B12054D6191611EB65D411AC2.description:
Writers appeal to (or
possibly manipulate) readers through
a variety of strategies and techniques
(e.g., language, authority, qualifiers,
fallacies, emphasis).

4BC27DFFDA5240BFA4219D76548D55DC.description:
Authors strategically include
evidence to support their claims.

7F53A8D5D7C64A048D6897F34C3CABF4.description:
Writers use qualitative
and/or quantitative evidence (e.g.,
facts, data, observations, predictions,
analogies, explanations, opinions) to
support their claims. Evidence has
varying degrees of validity.

5708A5E8D575437B89BE111799E21168.description:
An argument’s context
(time and purpose) and situation (in
relation to other arguments) inform
its interpretation.

52489DE572094F2CAF64F254AC96F6D1.description:
Evaluating the relevance
and credibility of evidence used
to support an argument, taking
context into consideration.

0B5EAA8D061B458B9FF6BF5E7EF0E747.description:
Effective arguments
acknowledge other arguments
and/or respond to them with
counterarguments (e.g., concession,
refutation, rebuttal).

02DAD9BA72D14ED8B0039E90F0B63ABD.description:
A lack of understanding
of the complexities of an
argument (tone, implications,
limitations, nuance, context) can
lead to oversimplification and/or
generalization.

F12677FD03A244EC9BCCDFA77F6DBD39.description:
Inductive reasoning uses
specific observations and/or data
points to identify trends, make
generalizations, and draw
conclusions. Deductive reasoning
uses broad facts or generalizations
to generate additional, more specific
conclusions about a phenomenon.

F4DFCA2C57CA4D6693CC5E9075F0AF52.description:
An argument’s line of
reasoning is organized based on the
argument’s purpose (e.g., to show
causality, to define, to propose a
solution).

18CFAB5A7E634A439E18CA4E56FCE15F.description:
Authors use reasons to
support their arguments. The line
of reasoning is composed of one
or more claims justified through
evidence.

7CABE7DCE3A54064B0F7FA46E95F177C.description:
Explaining and analyzing
the logic and line of reasoning of
an argument.

BB820E791FA141558C46F35AA170DB37.description:
Authors choose evidence
to shape and support their
arguments. Individuals evaluate
the line of reasoning and evidence
to determine to what extent they
believe or accept an argument.

419CA19DF03E45249F2CE8D11F684D3D.description:
Artistic works (e.g.,
painting, film, music, dance) convey
a perspective. Analysis of a work’s
context, subject, structure, style, and
aesthetic is critical to understanding
its aims.

C26096AC93534182AD0369BEA443C7C6.description:
The main idea of an
argument is often expressed in the
thesis statement, claim, or conclusion,
or implied throughout a work.

DC8819686CAE4870BFF6614167A5FF58.description:
Summarizing and
explaining a text’s main
idea or aim while avoiding
faulty generalizations and
oversimplification.

5160F2D9190A44D2A385909CD4674BA8.description:
Perspectives are shared
through written, spoken, visual, or
performance texts. A perspective
includes the writer’s attitude/tone
regarding the subject and is expressed
through an argument.

CEFD8D7B37C84FEFAA88E45BE6B93035.description:
Strategies active readers
use to make meaning from texts
include annotating, note-taking,
highlighting, and reading aloud.

F3DCD956E96E4D0E9F8467E35674B9A6.description:
Strategies active readers
use to preview and prioritize a written
text include skimming, scanning,
rereading, and questioning.

D3E56747EAC24DEBAF1BB90190B038C9.description:
Reading critically means
reading closely to identify the main
idea, tone, assumptions, context,
perspective, line of reasoning, and
evidence used.

CE9194E6A0BB41E4A763D943BF9F13DC.description:
Employing appropriate
reading strategies and reading
critically for a specific purpose.

414FF5F07611421DADF23032686BF04E.description:
Authors express their
ideas, perspectives, and/or
arguments through their works.
The first step in evaluating an
author’s perspective or argument
is to comprehend it. Such
comprehension requires reading,
viewing, listening, and thinking
critically.

32A9A6597A3B41899ABCFD9A0B78FF63.description:
The way the problem is posed,
situated, framed, or contextualized will
guide the inquiry process and influence
the type of information needed and the
appropriate method of gathering it.

5304A77C8F2E48A18D4733A11D5A9D42.description:
Identifying the
information needed for the
context of the inquiry

A5CACAC56E0746CE83AF64267D416FFF.description:
There are multiple ways to
investigate questions, problems,
and issues. Methods should be
aligned with the purpose of the
inquiry.

B83EBB571FEF45C3815343B9ED3530B5.description:
Determining the credibility
of a source requires considering and
evaluating the reputation and credentials
of the author, publisher, site owner,
and/or sponsor; understanding and
evaluating the author’s perspective and
research methods; and considering how
others respond to their work. Scholarly
articles are often peer reviewed,
meaning the research has been reviewed
and accepted by disciplinary experts.

EEB9DC1006BE4CE18A097F167CF35D30.description:
Credibility of evidence
depends on use of sources and data
that are relevant and reliable (current,
authoritative).

6D3993873F1746868AFE96A2F2E77DED.description:
The scope and purpose of
one’s research and the credibility of
sources affects the generalizability and
the reliability of the conclusions.

85023DCD61AC481080EE50E80E160805.description:
Evaluating the
relevance and credibility of the
source of information and data
in relation to the inquiry.

3EA50B96A49B4F5A930AE0B210A7B608.description:
The relevance and
credibility of the source of
information is determined by the
context of its use.

B4D1009C244B4A94BBBBD85B3C937161.description:
Advanced search tools, Boolean
logic, and key words allow scholars to
refine, focus, and/or limit their searches
based on a variety of factors (e.g., date,
peer-review status, type of publication).

DE4B031478C74BCD99EFB664D2C4B2D9.description:
Online databases (e.g.,
EBSCO, ProQuest, JSTOR, Google
Scholar) and libraries catalog and house
secondary and some primary sources.

A8A250DE59604BC29411461764061617.description:
Information used to address
a problem may come from various
secondary sources (e.g., articles, other
studies, analyses, reports) and/or
primary sources (e.g., original texts and
works, material culture, or personally
collected data such as from experiments,
surveys, questionnaires, interviews,
observations, personal narratives).

1E3548597303487D971A69748AC2934C.description:
Accessing and
managing information using
effective strategies.

A32F7F2C076A47E692CAB13FA38DA2FA.description:
The investigative process is
aided by the effective organization,
management, and selection
of resources and information.
Appropriate technologies and
tools enable the scholar to become
more efficient, productive, and
credible.

95D19D7EEC0A47C0A1262A16231165DE.description:
Inquiry confirms or
challenges one’s existing understandings,
assumptions, beliefs, and/or knowledge.

61ED040B584649CE945DE085E5529FC8.description:
A variety of strategies (e.g.,
brainstorming, concept mapping,
prewriting, exploration of space,
drafting) can be used to illustrate,
organize, and connect ideas.

9906CADA8840412C825E89B4F18BAAE9.description:
Understanding comes not
only through collection of information
but also from a variety of other factors
(e.g., experience, external sources,
cultural context, assumptions).

44949AAE4E4C4EC4B21A43C52225F846.description:
Retrieving, questioning,
organizing, and using prior
knowledge about a topic.

8441EC9C35FE41259791279485D0A559.description:
Strengthening
understanding of a concept or
issue requires questioning existing
ideas, using what is known to
discover what is not known, and
making connections to prior
knowledge.

02FF6169ACE541C3BF17765949CD4141.description:
The inquiry process allows
one to draw upon curiosity and
imagination to engage with ideas or
explore approaches to complex issues.

4F89FCFEBE424698A45BF94803B627B4.description:
Effective research questions
lead to an examination taking into
account the complexity of a problem
or issue.

468823706C28408C913C87658AA0C2D7.description:
Posing questions
and seeking out answers that
reflect multiple, divergent, or
contradictory perspectives.

D6613461955E4E7A8C9A4304C44DB3FC.description:
Examining the perspectives
and ideas of others often leads to
questions for further investigation.
Inquiry begins with narrowing scope
of interest, identifying a problem or
issue and its origins within that scope,
and situating the problem or issue in a
larger context.

88A2F354383D48E78574504DA53A0E10.description:
Contextualizing and
identifying the complexities of a
problem or issue.

44E705A756AB4DF4ABF41D00222003FD.description: Personal interest and intellectual curiosity inspire investigation of topics or issues that may or may not be clearly defined. A well-crafted investigation explores the complexity of an issue or topic. Further inquiry can lead to unexpected conclusions, resolutions, innovations, or solutions.
